author: Marc-André Brochu
title: Smart Contracts Tutorials
description: Developpers not used to working in Haskell and/or with blockchain tech find it hard to introduce themselves to smart contract development

assessments.note: The proposal does address the developer ecosystem challenge by proposing an concept that will make it easier for developers to work on the cardano platform

As a developer myself, this proposal is quite interesting, as we need more resources/tutorial to learn about smart contract in Cardano network. So, yes, I agree that this proposal is effectively address the challenge.

There are several sources that describe smart contracts very well. For example Dapp University. I also like the MIT OpenCourseWare Vidos about Blockchain and smart contracts. There are several free videos about it on youtube.  They might not be sepecific for Cardano but this aspect is also not mentioned in the proposal.
It's not clear how the explanation to developers should be delivered and what's the success criteria list.

The problem statement and solution presented are reasonable and address the challenge, but there is no description of a plan, so there is no way to assess the impact of the proposal in addressing the challenge.
This proposal if implemented, may benefit a handful of devs who prefer 1-1 learning from another dev, but will not have much reach beyond that.

The proposal addresses the keen need for a larger variety of tutorial materials for smart contracts, but is not specific about which smart-contract languages it will address or the types of smart contracts.
Proposal meets the challenge at a high level, but not a lot of detail provided.

Potentially, good idea. But that's about it. It doesn't really read like a proposal. Would have loved to learn how this concept ties together with the larger theme and where we can benefit from it. We can assume - education is always needed - but proposal needs to highlight those connections specifically so that we can understand author's narrative and intentions. At the moment - we don't know that much. Needs a bit more work to explore it's potential.
There is not enough information in the proposal regarding the plan and experience in  order to adequately assess it's implementation success probability

The proposer has relevant experience in blockchain technology. It would be great if there is a plan for the project itself. How does the proposer wants to realize the project (Youtube channel, Udemy, website, e-learning, etc.) It's not clear how the proposer going to implement the solution.
The stated expirience should okay for the creation of an introduction to the topics.
There's no clear plan of how to practically deliver Haskell courses to developers

There is no description of a plan. The proposer described experience as software development, but it is not clear what his level of experience with Haskell / blockchain is. I recommend that the proposal present a plan according to the Catalyst guidelines and documentation and that the proposer describes in detail his professional experiences / skills, in addition to adding a link to Github and Linkedin.
No discernible purpose or plan here.
It would indeed be useful to focus on mental models that facilitate building smart contracts, and the tools needed to build them, but this proposal does provide KPIs for success.

Experience and knowledge would appear to be suitable.
Unfortunately due to the lack of detail provided it is too difficult to determine if the proposal will be followed through and completed as intended.

Unfortunately, proposal doesn't offer appropriate depth in detail that could help us determine if A: there is enough valid experience to take this to production B: how/what the budget will be used for exactly. This may be due to the fact that this feels like a concept - more than an idea. There needs to be an actual plan presented as it is currently missing. So it isn't investable.
There is no information in the proposal regarding it's feasibility and how effectively it addresses the challenge.
The proposal lacks of information on the KPI, how does the implementation will affect/address the challenge.
The proposal contains no plan on how the solution will be implemented. Not technical and also not time-wise.

The proposal is not taking into consideration that there's already a series of Haskell coding classes organized by IOHK. In my opinion this is not adding nothing on top of what has been already planned.
There is not enough information to check how the proposal will impact/address the challenge. No metrics have been described to attest to the feasibility of the proposal.
Not enough information provided to measure if it's successful.
The proposal does not provide a justification for its budget, nor does it detail specific deliverables (number, types of contracts, languages, etc.).

Not enough information has been provided.
There is no outline of a general plan unfortunately.

As it reads like a concept - it lacks basic elements such as roadmap, milestones, success metrics, KPIs, challenges/risks considered and other usual suspects. I suggest visiting Catalyst Discord and reaching out for mentors to help you guide how to improve proposal. It has a good idea but just not enough for community to consider it seriously just yet. Please, rework and submit at later stages.

solution: Explain from the ground up the various mental models and tools required to understand, create and execute smart contracts
experience: I am a professional developper with a degree in maths and "on the side" experience with Haskell, smart contracts and blockchain tech
